Graphical abstract DFT calculations revealed that models incorporating sulfur vacancies, self-reconstruction, or high-entropy structures exhibited lower ΔGmax, with d-band centers closer to the Fermi level and a higher density of states (DOS) at the Fermi level. Guided by these theoretical insights, (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx and corresponding control samples were synthesized. As anticipated, (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx demonstrated outstanding OER performance, with an overpotential of 266 mV at 100 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 57.4 mV dec−1, along with remarkable stability. TEM, XPS, and ICP-AES analyses verified the leaching of Cr and Mo elements during OER. Furthermore, self-reconstruction of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx under OER was confirmed through XPS, TEM, and in situ Raman spectroscopy. The presence of sulfur vacancies was identified via EPR. These experimental findings aligned well with the initial DFT predictions. Currently, using Density Functional Theory (DFT) to drive the synthesis of targeted oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalysts, has attracted strong attention. Herein, sulfides were selected as the models. First, the density of states (DOS), active sites and the Gibbs free energy of intermediates (ΔG) of different models were calculated respectively. DFT results indicated that d-band centers of models with sulfur vacancies, self-reconstruction, or high entropy structures possessing lower ΔGmax, being closer to the Fermi level, exhibiting higher DOS at the Fermi level. To verify DFT results, thiourea was used as a precursor to prepare (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx for the first time. Indeed, (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx exhibited excellent OER activity (η100 = 266 mV, Tafel slope = 57.4 mV dec−1) and strong catalytic stability. The sulfur vacancies were confirmed by EPR experiments. TEM, XPS and ICP-AES all confirmed the leaching of Cr and Mo elements after OER. XPS, TEM and In situ Raman confirmed the self-reconstruction of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx during the OER. The above experimental results perfectly confirmed the initial DFT calculation. Keywords Density Functional Theory Self-reconstruction Sulfur vacancies Sulfides In situ Raman Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Generally, noble metal oxides such as RuO2 and IrO2 exhibit intrinsic high activity and are considered the most effective oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalysts [1,2]. However, the scarcity and high cost seriously restricted application [3–5]. Therefore, it is important to develop efficient and low-cost OER catalysts [6]. Transition metal sulfides (TMSs) have emerged as highly promising OER catalysts [7–10]. TMSs are abundant, cost-effective and commonly found in the world [11–13]. However, TMSs catalysts in the OER process generally expose fewer active sites and exhibit weak cyclic stability [14,15]. To enhance OER activity and catalytic stability, complex adjustments of chemical composition and surface electronic structures are both required. However, single metal sulfide generally cannot meet this requirement. Just recently, high-entropy sulfides (HES) as a young material with multiple advantages have garnered significant interest. Toward OER catalysis, the high entropy structure endows HES with two potential features [16–20]. First, HES contains five or more metal cations, providing a wide range of combinations for adjusting electronic and geometric structures to optimize catalytic activity. Second, the single-phase crystal structure of HES is stabilized via configurational entropy (Sconfig). The theoretical stability of HES with low Gibbs free energy can improve OER long-term durability. Despite these advantages, due to the incompatibility of multiple metal elements in HES, the synthesis of HES typically involves relatively complex or harsh reaction conditions, requiring high temperature or high pressure to ensure uniform mixing of various metal elements, making the synthesis of HES difficult [21,22]. For example, Cui et al. prepared the (CrMnFeCoNi)Sx nanoparticles as OER catalysts through a pulse thermal decomposition strategy [18]. For another example, Zhang et al. synthesized bulk solid materials Cu5SnMgGeZnS9 and Cu3SnMgInZnS7 using rapid heating and spark plasma sintering techniques [23]. In addition, Buravets et al. prepared two-dimensional high entropy sulfides using inorganic salts as precursors and CS2 as a sulfurizing agent, exhibiting excellent OER and HER properties [24]. E. Schaak et al. used a synchronous multi-cation exchange method to prepare high entropy metal sulfide. Roxbyite Cu1.8S nanoparticles reacted with a mixture of Zn2+, Co2+, In3+, and Ga3+ to generate Zn0.25Co0.22Cu0.28In0.16Ga0.11S, which was thermally stable. However, exchange reactions with fewer cations can not produce pure high entropy phases [25]. Actually, there are limited researches about how to drive the targeted HES catalysts for OER by effective theoretical predictions currently. Therefore, in this work, single, binary, ternary, quaternary metal sulfides and high entropy sulfides (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx, were initially designed as theoretical models for DFT calculations. The density of states (DOS), active sites and Gibbs free energy (ΔG) of intermediates for different models were calculated respectively. DFT results indicated that models with high-entropy structures, sulfur vacancies or self-reconstruction all exhibited d-band centers closer to the Fermi level, displaying higher DOS near the Fermi level. Thus, DFT results preliminarily predicted the potential OER activity of different models. Inspired by DFT results, high-entropy sulfides (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx and control samples were prepared. Notably, a solvothermal synthesis method with thiourea for preparing HES was first proposed in this work. Compared to single, binary, ternary, quaternary metal sulfides, the synthesized (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx exhibited a low overpotential of 266 mV at 100 mA cm−2, a favorable Tafel slope of 57.4 mV dec−1, and good stability in 1.0 M KOH, surpassing commercial noble metal RuO2 catalysts and most reported metal sulfide-based electrocatalysts to date. In-situ Raman spectroscopy, XPS, and TEM confirmed self-reconstruction of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx during OER. Sulfur vacancies were confirmed by EPR. TEM, XPS and ICP-AES all confirmed the leaching of Cr and Mo elements after OER. In this manner, a comprehensive array of materials characterization and electrochemical tests robustly validated the initial DFT predictions. Therefore, the concept of Density Functional Theory drive the design of target high entropy sulfide catalysts for OER was proposed. 2 Results and Discussion 2.1 Density of states, active sites and Gibbs free energy for high entropy sulfides and control models by DFT calculation For the NiSx catalyst, nickel atoms alternated with sulfur atoms to form three-dimensional structure, providing abundant active sites.The narrow band gap between the 2p orbitals of sulfur atoms and the 3d orbitals of Ni atoms facilitated redox reactions.Due to its good conductivity and chemical stability, NiSx can effectively promote the adsorption, dissociation, and release of oxygen, exhibiting excellent catalytic performance in OER [21,22,26]. NiSx was the OER catalyst with great potential. Therefore, NiSx was selected as the computational model in this work. Considering the common active metal components in OER and aiming to ensure the formation of single-phase structures, six models were designed for theoretical calculations: NiSx, (NiMo)0.5Sx, (CoNiMo)0.33Sx, (MnCoNiMo)0.25Sx, (MnCoCrMo)0.25Sx, and (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx. High-entropy sulfide structure models were constructed by random atom occupation to achieve special quasi-random structures (SQS), ensuring that the correlation function of the structures can closely match the cluster vectors of truly random alloys [27]. Within the cutoff radius, the high-entropy sulfide structure was constructed when the correlation function of each element was zero, indicating that the arrangement of transition elements in models was absolutely random, which meet the request of SQS. For the (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx structure, random atoms Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Mo were placed in the Ni atomic positions of the NiSx prototype structure based on their ratios, and the cluster vectors were optimized using the ICET package[28]. The density of states (DOS) results of NiSx, (NiMo)0.5Sx, (CoNiMo)0.33Sx, (MnCoNiMo)0.25Sx, (MnCoCrMo)0.25Sx, and (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx models were shown in Fig. 1 a∼f. As the number of metal species increased, the d-band center of sulfides became closer to the Fermi level (Table 1 ), being expected to lead to more adsorbed and occupied electrons in OER. The d-band center shifted towards the Fermi level, indicating that the number of antibonding orbitals above the Fermi level increased, which would strengthen chemical bonding with the adsorbate [4]. Therefore, it seemed like that high-entropy structure can effectively enhance the DOS of different atoms, introduce more catalytic sites, allow more charge carriers to directly participate in catalytic reactions, and have the potential to improve catalyst activity and promote the OER process. To determine the active site of NiSx, (NiMo)0.5Sx, (CoNiMo)0.33Sx, (MnCoNiMo)0.25Sx, (MnCoCrMo)0.25Sx, and (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx models in OER process, possible sites on the surface were enumerated, where the minimum adsorption energy corresponded to the optimum active site. For each intermediate (*OH, *O or *OOH) during the OER process, being tried to adsorb on each metal atoms. Beyond the top site, the hollow or bridge site of transition metal element was considered. In addition, the first-principles calculation software can only do the local optimization rather than global optimization, different orientations of the adsorbed intermediates were enumerated to further search for the optimum adsorbed site. The DFT calculation results indicated that the active site was Ni atom for NiSx, indicating that S atom was more inclined to form bonds in NiSx rather than provide active sites (Figs. S1−S5). For (NiMo)0.5Sx, intermediates (*OH, *O, or *OOH) all had the smallest adsorption energy (−1.42 eV;−2.00 eV;−1.50 eV) on Ni atoms, respectively.Therefore, its active site were Ni atoms (Figs. S6−S10).It was worth noting that for (CoNiMo)0.33Sx, the position located above two Co atoms and one Ni atom possessed the minimum adsorption energy for intermediates (*OH, *O, or *OOH) (−1.62 eV;−2.02 eV;−1.57 eV), respectively.This indicated that the Co and Ni atoms were both active sites (Figs. S11−S15).For (MnCoCrMo)0.25Sx, intermediates (*OH, *O, or *OOH) all had the smallest adsorption energy on Co atoms (−1.77 eV;−2.18 eV;−1.63 eV), respectively.The active sites were Co atoms (Figs. S16−S20).For (MnCoNiMo)0.25Sx, intermediates (*OH, *O, or *OOH) all had the smallest adsorption energy (−1.88 eV;−2.23 eV;−1.88 eV) on Ni atoms, respectively.Therefore, its active sites were Ni atoms (Figs. S21−S25).For the (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx model, it was not feasible to make intermediate *OH being adsorbed on Cr, Mn, and Co atoms due to the lack of bonding. While *OH can be adsorbed on Mo atoms, but its adsorption energy value (−1.57 eV) was bigger than that on Ni atoms (−1.98 eV). For intermediate *O, it can be adsorbed on Cr, Mn, Co, Ni and Mo atoms, while its adsorption energy value on Ni atoms was the lowest among them (−2.34 eV). Similar calculation results have been observed for intermediate *OOH, which can be adsorbed on Cr, Mn, Co, Ni and Mo atoms, while its adsorption energy value was the smallest on Ni atoms (−2.01 eV). In summary, Ni atoms were truly active sites for the (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx model (Figs. S26−S30). This was understandable considering the electronic structure of Ni atoms.The outer electronic configuration of Ni atom was 3d84s2,having abundant unsaturated d electrons. It can provide the electron transfer sites required for OER, promote the adsorption and dissociation of oxygen molecules, and thus accelerate the progress of OER [29]. Based on the adsorbate evolution mechanism (AEM), the variation in Gibbs free energy (ΔG) of different models were calculated to study the OER energy barrier (Fig. 1 g).As the number of elements increased, ΔGmax decreased, following the sequence: NiSx (ΔGmax = 3.85 eV) > (NiMo)0.5Sx (ΔGmax = 3.46 eV) > (CoNiMo)0.33Sx (ΔGmax = 3.12 eV) > (MnCoCrMo)0.25Sx (ΔGmax = 2.82 eV) > (MnCoNiMo)0.25Sx (ΔGmax = 2.57 eV) > (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx (ΔGmax = 1.97 eV). The above computational results indicated that the high-entropy structure can reduce ΔGmax, making it potential to possess better OER catalytic activity compared to the single, binary, ternary, quaternary metal sulfides. It was noteworthy that both as quaternary sulfides, the ΔGmax of (MnCoNiMo)0.25Sx (2.57 eV) was smaller than that of (MnCoCrMo)0.25Sx (2.82 eV), which may be attributed to the presence of Ni, accelerating the synergistic effects with other metal elements [10,30]. 2.2 Density of states, active sites and Gibbs free energy for the Self-reconstructed high entropy sulfides models by DFT calculations It was well-known that most metal sulfide catalysts generally had a dynamic and irreversible reconstruction process in an alkaline medium under anodic conditions, forming transition metal-based oxyhydroxide (MOOH, where M was the metal) as the actual catalytic species [21,31,32]. Therefore, a comprehensive understanding of the reconstruction behavior of sulfides was crucial for promoting the rational design and practical application of highly efficient OER catalysts. Considering the common types of MOOH, four models were designed in theoretical calculations: NiOOH-(CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx, CoOOH–(CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx, MnOOH-(CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx and high-entropy metal sulfides with surfaces simultaneously containing NiOOH, CoOOH, MnOOH (named as MnOOH-CoOOH-NiOOH-(CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx). For the high-entropy sulfide structures containing MOOH (M=Ni,Mn,Co), the heterojunction layer structures that combined a layer of MOOH and a layer of high-entropy sulfide structures were designed, where the lattice-matched heterojunction structures were constructed by SAGAR code [33]. For MnOOH-(CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx, intermediates (*OH, *O, or *OOH) all had the smallest adsorption energy (−2.18 eV;−2.50 eV;−2.45 eV) on Mn atoms, respectively.Therefore, its active site were Mn atoms (Figs. S31−S35).For CoOOH–(CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx, intermediates (*OH, *O, or *OOH) all had the smallest adsorption energy (−2.25 eV;−2.61 eV;−2.51 eV) on Co atoms, respectively.Therefore, its active site were Co atoms (Figs. S36−S40). For NiOOH-(CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx, intermediates (*OH, *O, or *OOH) all had the smallest adsorption energy (−2.39 eV;−2.71 eV;−2.64 eV) on Ni atoms, respectively.Therefore, its active site were Ni atoms (Figs. S41−S45).This was consistent with the results of many literatures [30]. For MnOOH-CoOOH-NiOOH-(CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx, intermediates (*OH, *O, or *OOH) all had the smallest adsorption energy (−2.39 eV;−2.83 eV;−2.74 eV) on Ni atoms, respectively.Therefore, its active site were Ni atoms (Figs. S46−S50).This indicated that when surface self-reconstruction of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx occurred in OER, NiOOH was more likely to adsorb different types of intermediates compared to CoOOH and MnOOH, which playing a major role. The center of the d-band in MnOOH-CoOOH-NiOOH-(CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx was closer to the Fermi level, compared to those of MnOOH-(CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx, CoOOH–(CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx and NiOOH-(CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx (Fig. 2 a∼d and Table 1). This indicated that an increase in the type of reconstructed MOOH on the surface would promote the center of the d-band to shift towards the Fermi level. Similar trends were observed for ΔGmax: MnOOH-CoOOH-NiOOH-(CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx (ΔGmax = 1.26 eV) < NiOOH-(CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx (ΔGmax = 1.39 eV) < CoOOH–(CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx (ΔGmax = 1.49 eV) < MnOOH-(CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx (ΔGmax = 1.57 eV) (Fig. 2 e). This demonstrated that an increase in the type of reconstructed MOOH on the surface can reduce ΔGmax. This was understandable, considering that different types of MOOH would produce a cumulative effect that was more conducive to regulating the adsorption, activation, and desorption behaviors of intermediate species in the OER reaction [10,12,30]. 2.3 Density of states, active sites and Gibbs free energy for the high entropy sulfides with sulfur vacancies model by DFT calculations To assess the impact of sulfur vacancies on Density of States (DOS) and Gibbs free energy, two models were designed: (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx with sulfur vacancies (Vs-(CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx), and CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx without sulfur vacancies ((CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx). For Vs-(CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx, intermediates (*OH, *O, or *OOH) all had the smallest adsorption energy (−2.04 eV;−2.46 eV;−2.40 eV) on Ni atoms, respectively.Therefore, its active site were Ni atoms (Figs. S51−S55). The d-band center of Vs-(CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx was found to be closer to the Fermi level compared to that of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx (Fig. 3 a). Moreover, the ΔGmax of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx (ΔGmax = 1.97 eV) was significantly higher than that of Vs-(CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx(ΔGmax = 1.68 eV) (Figs. 1g and 3 c). This indicated that sulfur vacancies not only can adjust the position of the d-band center but also reduce the energy barrier for intermediate transformations, potentially promoting the OER reaction. Finally, DOS and ΔGmax for the model Vs-MnOOH-CoOOH-NiOOH-(CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx was calculated, which possessed both sulfur vacancies and MOOH (M=Co, Ni, Mn) on the surface. For Vs-MnOOH-CoOOH-NiOOH-(CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx, intermediates (*OH, *O, or *OOH) all had the smallest adsorption energy (−2.49 eV;−2.97 eV;−2.87 eV) on Ni atoms, respectively.Therefore, its active site were Ni atoms (Figs. S56−S60). The d-band center of this model was found to be the closest to the Fermi level, and ΔGmax was the smallest among all models (ΔGmax = 1.12 eV) (Fig. 3 b∼c and Table 1). This suggested that the effects of high-entropy structure, surface reconstruction, and sulfur vacancies all can adjust the electronic structure and free energy of intermediates together without conflict. The synergistic effects were expected to enhance the OER catalytic performance. 2.4 Material preparation and structural characterization Inspired by DFT results, real experiments were conducted to verify the assumptions of DFT calculations. Due to the incompatibility of multiple metal elements, differences in atomic radii and coordination behaviors, the synthesis of high entropy sulfide (HES) usually required complex reaction equipment and harsh conditions of high temperature and pressure to ensure uniform mixing of various metal elements, making the synthesis of HES difficult [16,18,25]. In addition, the high-temperature would cause adverse effects on the morphology and size, and the high temperature required for phase transition lead to pore collapse, resulting in poor catalytic activity, hindering the OER application of HES. To address the aforementioned issues, thiourea was used as the source of sulfur element, (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx grown on NiFe foam was first synthesized by the solvothermal method in this work. Initially, various nitrates were reduced at 200 °C by ethylene glycol and then reacted with thiourea to obtain high entropy metal sulfide (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx. The advantage of this method was that low temperature can prevent grain coarsening, and increase the grain boundary density of the catalyst and the probability of exposing active centers, being potential to effectively improve catalytic activity. In addition, in-situ growth of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx on NiFe foam was expected to improve the transport efficiency and long-term cycling stability of active substances in the electrolyte [34]. As control samples, single, binary, ternary and quaternary sulfides were prepared using the same procedure. The preparation details were shown in Fig. 4 and Table S1. Initially, X-ray diffraction (XRD) experiment was conducted. (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx had a set of peaks at 26°, 28°, 29°, 38°, 45°, 50°, 53°, 54°, 55°, 62°, 70°, 72°, 74°, and 79° (Fig. 5 a), exhibiting a single-phase with MnS crystal structure (PDF#40–1289). The control samples NiSx, (NiMo)0.5Sx, (CoNiMo)0.33Sx, and (MnCoNiMo)0.25Sx were prepared under the same conditions. The XRD patterns of single metal sulfides NiSx were consistent with NiS (PDF#02–1280). When Mo, Co, and Cr elements were added sequentially, the binary metal sulfides (NiMo)0.5Sx, ternary metal sulfides (CoNiMo)0.33Sx, and quaternary metal sulfides (MnCoNiMo)0.25Sx were obtained. However, for (NiMo)0.5Sx, (CoNiMo)0.33Sx, and (MnCoNiMo)0.25Sx, mixed phase (NiS PDF#02–1280 and NiS2 PDF#11–0099); single phase NiS2 (PDF#11–0099); and mixed phase (NiS2 PDF#11–0099 and MnS PDF#40–1289) were observed respectively (Fig. S61). Given the consideration of configuration entropy (Sconfig), this result was comprehensible. Sconfig increased with the growing number of atomic arrangements. When all elements existed in equal atomic fractions, Sconfig reached its maximum value. In an equi atomic 5-cation system, the maximum Sconfig value was 1.61R. The dependence relationship between the mixing free energy (ΔGmix), mixing enthalpy (ΔHmix), and mixing entropy (ΔSmix) was represented by Equation (2) (2) Δ G m i x = Δ H m i x - T Δ S m i x In many cases, if Sconfig ≥ 1.5 R, single-phase can be achieved because at this point TΔSmix can be large enough to dominate the free energy pattern and overcome ΔHmix. The uniform arrangement of five or more equimolar metal elements in a single-phase lattice, generated by Sconfig, resulted in lower ΔGmix, favoring the formation of a single-phase crystal structure. Therefore, under the same solvothermal conditions, high-entropy sulfides (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx were easier to form a single phase compared to binary, ternary, and quaternary sulfides. Then, the morphology of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx was observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (Fig. 5 b∼c). (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx was composed of spheres with a diameter range of 100–200 nm, which was obtained by aggregating smaller rough particles. Similar morphology was also observed for control samples (Fig. S62). In addition, Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) images (Fig. 5 d) showed that (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx was solid nanospheres. High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscope (HRTEM) confirmed the crystal phase of the (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx. Three different lattice distances 0.198 nm, 0.304 nm, and 0.235 nm were observed, corresponding to the (110), (101), and (102) planes of MnS respectively. Selected area electron diffraction (SAED) was conducted to further confirm the crystallinity of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx ( Fig. 5 e), which was consistent well with the XRD patterns of MnS (PDF#40–1289). The Energy Dispersive Spectrometer (EDS) elemental image showed that Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Mo, S, and O were uniformly distributed within the nanostructure domain, providing another evidence for the formation of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx ( Fig. 5 h). In a solvothermal reaction, nitrates were reduced by ethylene glycol, then thiourea was thermally decomposed and reacted with them, ultimately forming nanospheres. This process may be beneficial for the uniform dispersion of five different metal species. Sulfides may be partially oxidized to sulfates, so the O element may come from sulfates. Sulfate was not detected in the XRD spectrum, possibly due to its amorphous properties. This was consistent with the literature [16]. In addition, N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were conducted (Figs. S63−S67). The specific surface area gradually increased in order with the increase of metal elements, indicating that the specific surface area of sulfides can be somewhat improved by elements types. This allowed (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx to have more contact with the electrolyte and expose more active sites, being positive for improving catalytic activity. This phenomenon was understandable, considering that (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx was single-phase, which mean that different metal ions occupy the same position in the lattice. In addition, due to multiple elements being located at the same crystal position, (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx exhibited significant structural disorder. Therefore, compared to the control samples, the particles of the (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx obtained during the solvothermal process was smaller, the crystallization was slower, leading to a higher specific surface area [13,21]. In addition, all sulfides exhibited porous structures. 2.5 Electrocatalytic performance To verify DFT calculations, OER activity was evaluated. In order to determine the actual loading of catalyst coating on NiFe foam, the weight before and after OER reaction were compared (Table S2). Fig. 6 a showed the linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) curve of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx, (MnCoNiMo)0.25Sx, (CoNiMo)0.33Sx, (NiMo)0.5Sx, NiSx and NiFe foam after iR correction. At 100 mA cm−2, the overpotential of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx was 266 mV, which was superior to that of commercial RuO2 (η100 = 346 mV, Fig. S74). In addition, at 100 mA cm−2, the overpotential of (MnCoNiMo)0.25Sx (287 mV), (MnCoCrMo)0.25Sx (289 mV), (CoNiMo)0.33Sx (295 mV), (NiMo)0.5Sx (299 mV), NiSx (305 mV) and NiFe foam samples (452 mV) increased by 21, 23, 29, 33, 39 mV and 186 mV compared to (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx respectively (Fig. 6 b). Obviously, the catalytic activity increased with the increase of element types. In addition, the OER reaction kinetics were studied by analyzing the Tafel slope of the LSV curve and the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) plot. The Tafel slope of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx was only 57.4 mV dec−1, which was smaller than that of NiSx (98.3 mV dec−1), (NiMo)0.5Sx (88.7 mV dec−1), (CoNiMo)0.33Sx (87.1 mV dec−1), (MnCoNiMo)0.25Sx (80.8 mV dec−1), and NiFe foam (102.5 mV dec−1) (Fig. 6 c). EIS spectrum of sulfides showed (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx had a semicircle representing charge transfer resistance (Rct) with the smallest semicircle, indicating faster charge transfer compared to control samples (Fig. 6 d). In order to further reveal the activity of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx, the effective electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) was measured by double-layer capacitance (Cdl). As shown in Fig. 6 e, multiple CV scans were performed on the sample at 20–100 mV/s, and the Cdl value of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx was fitted to be 15.06mF cm−2. The Cdl value increased with the number of metal types, and (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx showed a higher Cdl value than that of the control sample (Fig. S68), indicating that (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx can expose more active sites. Then, according to the formula ECSA=Cdl/Cs, the ECSA value of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx was determined to be 376.5 cm−2 (Fig. 6 f and Table S3). (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx had the highest specific surface area among samples, which may lead to higher ECSA compared to the control samples. The lower overpotential of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx can be understood if considering that the D-band center of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx was closer to the Fermi level, and the smallest free energy (ΔGmax = 1.97 eV) compared to control samples(ΔGmax = 2.57∼3.85 eV). Therefore, the above experimental results perfectly validated the DFT prediction. Meanwhile, compared to the catalysts recently reported in many literatures at 10 mA cm−2 and 100 mA cm−2, (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx prepared in this work had better performance (Table S4). Then, the intrinsic reaction kinetics at the electrode/electrolyte interface were studied by in situ EIS. Figs. S69a−S73a showed Nyquist plots of various catalysts, indicating that the resistance decreased with an increase in external voltage. (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx exhibited the lowest resistance at all potentials compared with the control sample, indicating that the synergistic effect between multi-components of the high entropy structure can significantly enhance the adsorption kinetics of oxygen-containing active species in OER. The Bode diagram can effectively illustrate the phase relaxation process, as shown in Figs. S69b−S73b. The peaks in the low-frequency regions correspond to the charge transfer reaction at the interface between the electrolyte and the catalyst, while the peaks in the high-frequency regions correspond to the electron conduction in the internal layer of the catalyst [35]. For (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx and control samples, the phase angle shifts towards the high-frequency region with the potential increasing, indicating that the transfer resistance during the reaction process mainly comes from the electron transfer process in the inner layer of the catalyst. This also suggested that the electron transfer process in the inner layer of the catalyst was faster than the electron transfer at the interface between the electrolyte and the catalyst, resulting in a decrease in transfer resistance as the potential increases [10,29]. In addition to the inherent electrocatalytic activity, long-term stability was also important to evaluate the catalyst performance. The LSV curve of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx in Fig. 6 g showed that the activity of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx slightly increased after 1000 CV cycles. This may be due to the incomplete activation of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx in the early stages. Meanwhile, it can be shown that the (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx catalyst exhibited good stability under dynamic current [36,37]. Fig. 6 h∼i indicated that the (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx catalyst can maintain stability under different current densities and potentials. At 150 mA cm−2, there was no significant increase in the required potential for the (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx catalyst after 100 h (Fig. 6 j). These results indicated that the (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx catalyst had excellent electrolytic sustainability. This was understandable considering the structural characteristics of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx. For high entropy sulfides, five or more equimolar metal elements were intentionally arranged in a uniformly distributed single-phase lattice. Compared with single sulfides, the strain effect caused by lattice distortion had a promoting effect on catalytic activity in thermodynamics (ΔGmix = ΔHmix-TΔSmix) and dynamics (diffusion through vacancy mechanisms) can form more stable crystal structures, thus ensuring long-term stability during the electrocatalytic process [23,38]. 2.6 Self-reconstruction of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx DFT calculations have shown that self-reconstruction was beneficial for electron transfer and optimizes the adsorption of reaction intermediates. Therefore, it was necessary to verify the true existence of the self-reconstruction phenomenon of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx in the OER process through real experiments. Initially, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed to analyze the valence states of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx before and after OER (Fig. 7 ). For the Ni 2p spectra, it can be observed that Ni2+ appeared peaks at 853.4 and 870.9 eV (Ni 2p1/2), while Ni3+ appeared peaks at 857.3 eV (Ni 2p3/2) and 875.2 eV (Ni 2p1/2). The 862.7 and 881.5 eV belong to two satellite peaks. In the Co 2p spectrum, Co 2p3/2 (Co3+) dissociated into two peaks at 781.3 eV and 794.2 eV, with Co 2p3/2 (Co2+) and Co 2p1/2 (Co2+) peaks at 782.6 and 797.9 eV, respectively. The two peaks located at 786.9 and 803.6 eV were satellite peaks [39]. The peaks at 637.2 (Mn 2p3/2) and 651.8 eV (Mn 2p1/2) belong to Mn2+, while the peaks at 642.5 (Mn 2p3/2) and 656.8 eV (Mn 2p1/2) belong to Mn3+. The peak at 648.2 eV was a satellite peak.[8,18,32] Compared to that before OER, the molar content of Ni3+, Co3+, and Mn3+ increased respectively after OER, which may be due to the generation of NiOOH, CoOOH and MnOOH [16]. For the S 2p spectra, the peak at 162.7 eV (S 2p3/2) and 163.9 eV (S 2p1/2) correspond to the S2- of metal disulfides; the peak at 169.2 eV belong to the sulfate component (SO4 2-), which may be attributed to the partial oxidation of sulfur species by air. After the OER reaction, S2- disappeared, leaving only SO4 2-, which was consistent with literature reports. The presence of SO4 2- has been demonstrated in literature to enhance OER activity [16]. In addition, for the O 1 s XPS, the peak at 529 eV corresponds to the M−O bond on the catalyst surface, the peak at 531.2 eV correspond to the M−OH bond, and the peak at 532.2 eV correspond to the chemically adsorbed water. Compared with that before OER, the concentration of M−O bonds after OER became higher (Fig. 7 g), which can be attributed to the recombination of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx during OER, resulting in highly active oxyhydroxide species (NiOOH, CoOOH, and MnOOH), which matched well with the results of Ni 2p, Mn 2p, and Co 2p XPS. (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx exhibited good OER activity and stability, generally indicating its structural and chemical stability. However, SEM analysis of the (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx after OER showed significant morphological transformation (Fig. 8 a). The spherical structure transformed into a porous sponge-like structure after OER. This may be related to self-reconstruction. In addition to the MnS crystal phase, new crystalline regions have emerged. The d-spacing calculated by HTEM and SAED indicated that 1.11 Å corresponded to the CoOOH (205) [40]. 1.45 Å and 1.30 Å belonged to the crystal plane (002) of NiOOH and the crystal plane (321) of MnOOH, respectively ( Fig. 8 c∼f) [41]. Therefore, the above TEM results provided scientific evidence for self-reconstruction from a crystallographic perspective. In order to further prove self-reconstruction of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx during OER, in-situ Raman spectroscopy experiments were conducted. When the voltage was less than 1.22 V (relative to RHE), (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx showed no peak (Fig. 9 a). Two new peaks appeared at a potential ≥ 1.22 V. The two new peaks at 465 and 555 cm−1 correspond to the MOOH vibration mode [9,42]. These MOOH peaks continued to increase until the potential reached 1.52 V. The results indicated that (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx was converted into MOOH. Similar results were observed for the control samples (Fig. 9 b∼f). In summary, XPS, TEM, and in situ Raman spectroscopy results all demonstrated the real self-reconstruction during the OER. This also confirmed the self-reconstruction included in the initial DFT calculation assumption, which was beneficial for OER. 2.7 Cr and Mo leaching during the OER It was worth noting that the EDS elemental results showed that Ni, Co, Mn were uniformly distributed in (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx after OER. However, the signals of Cr and Mo elements were relatively weak after OER(Fig. 8 h). In addition, Cr 2p and Mo 3d XPS experiments were conducted before and after OER, Cr 2p XPS before OER exhibited the oxidation state of Cr3+, with peaks at Cr 2p3/2 (577 eV) and Cr 2p1/2 (586.2 eV) [43]. In the Mo 3d XPS spectrum before OER, the binding energies at 229.1 and 232.3 eV can be attributed to the Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2 components of Mo4+ in (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx [44]. In addition, the signal at 235.7 eV can be attributed to the Mo6+ state. After 1000 cycles, the Cr 2p peak and Mo 3d peak almost disappeared (Fig. 7 e∼f). Moreover, (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx before and after OER were subjected to ICP-AES experiments. The results showed that before OER, the content of five elements was similar (Table S5). After OER reaction, the content of Cr and Mo elements decreased compared to before OER (Table S6). The results of EDS, XPS and ICP-AES all indicated that most of Cr and Mo may leach from the surface of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx during the OER process. This result was consistent with previous research [29]. These above results prompted us to hypothesize the ion leaching process of the (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx catalyst in the OER process. Over time, Cr and Mo leached from the surface of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx, resulting in a change in the morphology and an increase in porosity [45]. The increase in porosity increased ECSA and created a loose interface in the catalyst particles, promoting better electrolyte penetration and diffusion/adsorption of active components on active sites [46]. As a result, more accessible active sites were provided, thereby improving the activity of OER. 2.8 Sulfur vacancies generated during the OER Electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy (EPR) experiments were conducted to quantitatively determine the vacancy concentration and type in (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx (Fig. 8 i). The signal peak at g = 2.004 was classified as the characteristic signal peak of sulfur vacancies [13,47,48]. Based on the strength of peak, (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx after OER (6.58*1014 spins/g) > (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx before OER (4.63*1014 spins/g), confirming that a large number of sulfur vacancies were generated during the OER process, providing a scientific explanation for the excellent OER activity of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx, and also verifying the DFT theoretical prediction. 3 Conclusion To sum up, a concept that Density Functional Theory (DFT) drive to design the target high entropy sulfides (HES) catalysts for OER was proposed in this work. Initially, (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx and control models were designed for DFT calculations. The density of states (DOS) results indicated that models with high-entropy structures, sulfur vacancies or self-reconstruction all exhibited d-band centers closer to the Fermi level, displaying higher DOS near the Fermi level. Furthermore, the electronic structure of active sites can be adjusted to reduce Gibbs free energy (ΔG). Thus, DFT calculations preliminarily predicted the potential OER activity of different models. Inspired by DFT calculations, (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx and control samples were prepared with thiourea as a precursor for the first time, which overcame the strict requirements of traditional methods for high temperature and high pressure. Compared to single, binary, ternary, quaternary metal sulfides, (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx exhibited a low overpotential of 266 mV at 100 mA cm−2, a favorable Tafel slope of 57.4 mV dec−1, and robust catalytic durability. In-situ Raman spectroscopy, XPS, and TEM all confirmed the self-reconstruction of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx during the OER. Sulfur vacancies were confirmed by EPR. TEM, XPS and ICP-AES all confirmed the leaching of Cr and Mo elements after OER. In summary, a comprehensive array of materials characterization and electrochemical experiments robustly validated the initial DFT predictions. This work used DFT calculations to predict and drive the synthesis of targeted HES catalysts for OER, which was just the beginning. In the future, there will be more research combining theory and experiment to synthesize efficient OER catalysts. CRediT authorship contribution statement Mengyuan Zhang: Writing – original draft. coredata.dc:description: Currently, using Density Functional Theory (DFT) to drive the synthesis of targeted oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalysts, has attracted strong attention. Herein, sulfides were selected as the models. First, the density of states (DOS), active sites and the Gibbs free energy of intermediates (ΔG) of different models were calculated respectively. DFT results indicated that d-band centers of models with sulfur vacancies, self-reconstruction, or high entropy structures possessing lower ΔGmax, being closer to the Fermi level, exhibiting higher DOS at the Fermi level. To verify DFT results, thiourea was used as a precursor to prepare (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx for the first time. Indeed, (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx exhibited excellent OER activity (η100 = 266 mV, Tafel slope = 57.4 mV dec−1) and strong catalytic stability. The sulfur vacancies were confirmed by EPR experiments. TEM, XPS and ICP-AES all confirmed the leaching of Cr and Mo elements after OER. XPS, TEM and In situ Raman confirmed the self-reconstruction of (CrMnCoNiMo)0.2Sx during the OER. The above experimental results perfectly confirmed the initial DFT calculation.
